title-group.article-title: Low-Cost LED Annular Illuminator for Intraoral Photography

body.p: Photodocumentation is an essential part of good clinical practice. Accurate depiction of pathology can improve preoperative planning, enhance communication, and provide a medical-legal record.1

High quality intraoral photography remains a challenge. Maintaining the necessary depth-of-field to keep both the anterior and posterior parts of the oral cavity in focus requires either very bright illumination or high dynamic-range image sensors. The eccentrically placed, integrated flash units on most mass-market cameras produce unacceptable shadows and distracting reflections from moist mucosal surfaces. Specialty digital single-lens reflex (SLR)–style cameras with macrolenses and dedicated ring flashes avoid these problems but cost in the $3000 to $5000 range.2 Furthermore, ring flashes produce uniform light output, which creates a flat, lackluster image.3 Fine focus and color control can be difficult using any flash system. Fortunately, some of these limitations can be overcome by combining recently developed light sources with the low-light image sensors now found in newer commercial digital cameras.

High-intensity LEDs are replacing conventional light sources for many medical applications. These LEDs have a greater luminous efficiency and longer life span than incandescent sources,4 and they produce much less heat than xenon and mercury short-arc plasma lamps. Individual LEDs have limited power output so are commonly grouped into arrays to enhance brightness.

The latest generation of home digital SLR-style cameras features large image sensors that function well in low light. These inexpensive cameras are gradually replacing professional models for routine office and operating room documentation. The Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ18 camera (Panasonic, Osaka, Japan) we use and similar 14-megapixel recreational cameras begin at about $400. In macro mode, the camera focuses as close as 1 cm from its subject. The camera’s microprocessor features optical image stabilization to reduce shake. Its f2.8 macro-zoom Leica lens maintains image quality to ISO 6400.

Even with the flexibility afforded by large image sensors, good intraoral photography requires well-distributed supplemental light. We have combined a Panasonic Lumix digital SLR camera with a commercially available LED annular illuminator—originally designed for use with an industrial field microscope. The Lylight YK-S48T (Lylight, Zhejiang, China)5 is a 48-LED ring array that sells for $45 in the United States. It yields 15,000 Lux at 100 mm, and its color temperature (6400 K) is similar to daylight. The array is powered either by a small (120- to 240-V AC) transformer or can operate from a 12-V DC battery source. The ring’s inner diameter of 61 mm fits neatly over the lens barrel of many SLR-style cameras and is secured with thumb screws (Figure 1).

caption.p: A home digital single-lens reflex (SLR)–style camera with attached Lylight YK-S48T LED array microscope illuminator.

body.p: The LED array provides continuous illumination. Thus, the camera can be critically focused through the viewfinder—a difficult task with flash photography. The images are bright and free of excessive reflection. The LED array produces sufficient shadowing to avoid the flat look of ring flashes.6 The digital images are easily stored as part of the electronic medical record and can be merged into letters and operative reports (Figure 2).

caption.p: An intraoral photograph using this system. It allows good depth-of-field and accurate color while avoiding the flat look produced by ring flashes.

body.p: The combination of new-generation LED illuminators and low-cost, high-performance digital cameras overcomes several of the longstanding obstacles to good medical photography in the head and neck.
